definition: abbr. for Heilongjiang province 黑龍江|黑龙江[Hei1 long2 jiang1]
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]

sentences.english: A dead horse is quite different from a dark horse.
sentences.chinese: 死马和黑马又完全不同。

sentences.english: The resulting bitboard contains all of the possible moves of Black's knights.
sentences.chinese: 得出的位棋盘中包含了所有可能的黑马步法。

sentences.english: I was once with a girl who took one look, giggled, and named him the Dark Horse.
sentences.chinese: 曾经我让一个女生看过一次，她笑着，并说它是黑马。

sentences.english: Even when it's applied to a self-declared, multi-platinum dark horse.
sentences.chinese: 即使当它适用于自我申报，多白金的一匹黑马。

sentences.english: I think there may be some surprises, some dark horses.
sentences.chinese: 我想可能会有一些出乎意料的合约，出现一些黑马。

sentences.english: She was indeed the dark horse.
He had a splendid black horse with a richly embroidered saddle-cloth .
sentences.chinese: 他骑的是一匹顶呱呱的黑马，鞍鞯绣得很华丽。

sentences.english: Wang is the dark horse for Yankees this year.
sentences.chinese: 王建民是今年洋基队的黑马。

sentences.english: He is regarded as a dark horse in the year-end election.
sentences.chinese: 他在年底的选举中被认为是匹黑马。

sentences.english: All systems are go for Channing Frye as a fantasy sleeper this season.
sentences.chinese: 所有迹象表明钱宁弗莱这个赛季会是个黑马。

sentences.english: She bet a month's salary on the black horse.
sentences.chinese: 她对那匹黑马下了一个月的薪水的赌注。

sentences.english: Sevilla could be a surprise this season and will avoid playing relegation football.
sentences.chinese: 塞维利亚不会陷入保极圈，他们将是本赛季的黑马。

sentences.english: She wagered ten dollars on that black horse.
sentences.chinese: 她在那匹黑马身上下了十美元的赌注。

definition: to emerge as a new force to be reckoned with (idiom)
lit. only one branch of the tree is thriving (idiom)/fig. to be in a league of one's own/outstanding
to force one's way out of encirclement/to break through
to amaze the world with a single brilliant feat (idiom); an overnight celebrity
to advance boldly/to push ahead vigorously
lit. late-comer lives above (idiom); the up-and-coming youngster outstrips the older generation/the pupil surpasses the master
New Armies (modernized Qing armies, trained and equipped according to Western standards, founded after Japan's victory in the First Sino-Japanese War in 1895)
